# What Could The Future Hold For AI Regulation?
## What can lawyers expect as the talk of AI continues to grow? Join us for this CLE-eligible webinar on October 11th for find out more.
By Ontra and Above The Law  
onSeptember 21, 2023 at 12:47 PMSeptember 21, 2023 at 11:30 AM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/what-could-the-future-hold-for-ai-regulation/&text=What%20Could%20The%20Future%20Hold%20For%20AI%20Regulation?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/what-could-the-future-hold-for-ai-regulation/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/what-could-the-future-hold-for-ai-regulation/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When it comes to the tech industry, the 2020s have been a decade of emerging rules.

But will the same hold true as the use of artificial intelligence quickly grows?

Join us and our friends at Ontra for this CLE-eligible webinar on Oct. 11 at 1 p.m. ET, where our expert panel will explore the potential for regulation of AI.

We’ll also look at what regulatory developments could mean in practice, particularly for in-house law departments.

The discussion will include:

>Emerging intellectual property and data security concerns
>Potential effects on legal ethics rules
>Past regulation of emerging technologies
>Practical applications — and how you can avoid pitfalls

Please fill out the form and join the discussion!

####Topics
[AI Legal Beat](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ai-legal-beat/), [Artificial Intelligence (AI)](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/artificial-intelligence-ai/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [CLE](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/cle/), [Ontra](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ontra/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/technology/), [Webinars](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/webinars/)

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.
By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Biglaw Firm Decides To Take A Back Seat To Elite Firms On Compensation
## All the firm needs are warm bodies with a J.D.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 3, 2018 at 1:42 PMAugust 3, 2018 at 12:53 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firm-decides-to-take-a-back-seat-to-elite-firms-on-compensation/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Decides%20To%20Take%20A%20Back%20Seat%20To%20Elite%20Firms%20On%20Compensation)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firm-decides-to-take-a-back-seat-to-elite-firms-on-compensation/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firm-decides-to-take-a-back-seat-to-elite-firms-on-compensation/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Not every Biglaw firm is created the same. At no time is that more apparent then during Biglaw raise season. The summer’s new associate compensation scale, that starts at $190,000 for first-year associates, was ushered in by Milbank, but not every big-time firm can match it.

Wiley Rein called an associate meeting where the managing partner announced that associates will not be getting raises. While there may be some small kindness in letting associates know not to hold their breath waiting for a raise that will never come, it still has to sting to know your firm can’t keep up with the Cravaths. Sources at the firm report that while there was an acknowledgement that this will obviously have an impact on the firm’s ability to recruit talented students out of law school and retain them once they’re at the firm, they’re not worried. As a tipster says:

Firm thinks everything will be fine since there’s plenty of law students out there.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Well, if all you need are warm bodies with a J.D., the firm should have plenty of options. But folks at the firm seemed surprised at the candor of the announcement:

Was surprising that he would speak that way, since he must have known it would leak to Above the Law.

Yeah, that’ll happen. Especially when the lack of raises or bonuses has left the firm with, to quote a tipster, “a lot of angry associates.”

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises%20Salaries) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises Salaries”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks!

# Biglaw Firm Gives Associates A Major Halloween Treat In The Form Of Raises
## The raises are retroactive to the beginning of 2021, so this is an especially nice treat.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 28, 2021 at 11:50 AMOctober 28, 2021 at 11:50 AM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/biglaw-firm-gives-associates-a-major-halloween-treat-in-the-form-of-raises/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Gives%20Associates%20A%20Major%20Halloween%20Treat%20In%20The%20Form%20Of%20Raises)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/biglaw-firm-gives-associates-a-major-halloween-treat-in-the-form-of-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/biglaw-firm-gives-associates-a-major-halloween-treat-in-the-form-of-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Happy Halloween, associates! One Biglaw firm just gave its associates the best treat of all: raises. That’s right, it’s the end of October and law firms are still handing out raises. Which firm is the latest to scare up an increase in compensation?

That would be Littler — the world’s largest employment firm — which brought in $613,640,000 gross revenue in 2020, ranking it at No. 69 in the most recent Am Law 100. Yesterday, during a video town hall presentation, the firm announced raises for all U.S. associates, effective immediately and retroactive to January 1, 2021. The raises are based on market and associate level, and will range from $5,000 to $25,000. An insider at the firm says everyone is “really happy,” and particularly happy with the retroactive nature of the raise. In a way, it’s like associates at Littler are getting a little Halloween “bonus.”

Salaries at he firm are highly individualized, and while Littler’s salary bump may not match the Davis Polk money that’s become the prevailing rate in most major markets ($202.5K for the Class of 2021 and $205K for the Class of 2020, to be specific), money is money, so congratulations to everyone at the firm!

Thanks for all of your help!

# We've Lost A Lot Of Biglaw Firms This Decade. This Is One Of Them.
## Gone, but not forgotten.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 26, 2019 at 3:00 PMDecember 26, 2019 at 9:29 AM
15

What now defunct Biglaw firm was founded in 1956 by four antitrust attorneys?

Hint: The firm had a 50+ year run, with 16 offices and over 500 attorneys when it announced its dissolution in 2011.

# Lawyers From Biglaw Firms Across The World Sign Statement Of Support For Israel After Terror Attacks
## It's time for lawyers to speak up on behalf of their Jewish colleagues.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 13, 2023 at 11:12 AMOctober 16, 2023 at 11:36 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/lawyers-from-biglaw-firms-across-the-world-sign-statement-of-support-for-israel-after-terror-attacks/&text=Lawyers%20From%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Across%20The%20World%20Sign%20Statement%20Of%20Support%20For%20Israel%20After%20Terror%20Attacks)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/lawyers-from-biglaw-firms-across-the-world-sign-statement-of-support-for-israel-after-terror-attacks/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/lawyers-from-biglaw-firms-across-the-world-sign-statement-of-support-for-israel-after-terror-attacks/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
While many of the world’s largest law firms have issued public or internal statements affirming their support for Israel in the wake of the brutal Hamas attacks on Jewish civilians, many other firms simply have not.

This lack of meaningful action is not sitting well attorneys, and they can be silent no longer.

Leading lawyers from prominent law firms around the world recently published a powerful statement — written by [Alex Kaufman](https://www.paulhastings.com/professionals/alexkaufman) of Paul Hastings — condemning the terrorist attacked in Israel and supporting Israel’s right to self-defense. You can read the statement below.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
We, the undersigned group of attorneys from around the world, publicly condemn and denounce the unspeakable acts of mass terror perpetrated by Hamas, a recognized terrorist organization, against civilians in Israel.

We stand for the rule of law. We are shocked and horrified by the ghastly barbarism carried out against innocent civilians. We are angered by the cowardly crimes against humanity committed and the massive scale on which they were perpetrated.

We stand for moral consistency. We are profoundly disturbed by the litany of free people throughout the world who are indifferent, or even hostile, when confronted with Jewish suffering.

We stand against injustice. We therefore affirm that Israel has the undeniable right and obligation to pursue justice against those who harm it and murder its citizens, and to defend itself against further aggression.

We stand for peace. We affirm the right of all people – Jews and non-Jews – to live in peace and security, and we wholeheartedly reject the moral equivalence of bloodthirsty terrorists and Israel’s imperative to defend its population.

Finally, we affirm the promise made by our forebears — that never again will Jews sit by while other Jews are slaughtered en masse.

We call on our colleagues in the legal profession and elsewhere to stand with us and denounce terrorism against Israel and Jews throughout the world.

At the time of publication, more than 1,500 attorneys have signed on to this important statement. To add your name to the list of signatories, please click [here](https://www.ipetitions.com/petition/global-lawyers-condemn-terrorism-in-Israel).

Please stand with Israel. Please donate. Please support your Jewish friends and colleagues. Am Yisrael Chai.

[Leading Lawyers From Around the World Publish Statement Condemning Terrorism in Israel](https://www.ipetitions.com/petition/global-lawyers-condemn-terrorism-in-Israel) [iPetitions]

# Morning Docket: 10.18.19
## * Did you know over 100 firms have reported data breaches since 2014? Something to make you feel warm and fuzzy. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2019/10/17/how-vendor-data-breaches-are-putting-law-firms-at-risk/)] * If you were wondering how conservatives would spin Mick Mulvaney admitting to a quid pro quo holding up foreign assistance in exchange for personal political vendettas, Laura Ingraham's attempt was to say it was all a misunderstanding because Mulvaney's not a lawyer. Ron Howard Arrested Development voice: Mick Mulvaney is a lawyer. [[Daily Beast](https://www.thedailybeast.com/laura-ingraham-mick-mulvaney-admitted-to-quid-pro-quo-because-hes-not-a-lawyer-except-he-is)] * Appellate court says it's illegal to watch porn in your car in New Jersey. Sorry if that forces some of you to change your weekend plans. [[New Jersey 12](http://newjersey.news12.com/story/41196407/appellate-court-watching-porn-in-your-car-not-allowed)] * Anheuser-Busch files counterclaim accusing MillerCoors of stealing their recipes for sub-par beer. [[STL Today](https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/a-b-claims-millercoors-broke-law-by-stealing-recipes-and/article_1d888f95-8ee4-5232-85e8-ebd74c9e223a.html)] * TransPerfect to be fined $30K/day until it drops litigation in Nevada. [[Delaware Online](https://www.delawareonline.com/story/money/business/2019/10/18/transperfect-found-contempt-delaware-court-faces-fines-30-k-day/4011754002/)] * After Greenberg Traurig [threw shade on the Dentons U.S. expansion plans](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/10/15/greenberg-traurig-chair-takes-aim-at-what-makes-a-truly-national-firm/), Joe Andrew of Dentons responds to those "Parochial and Condescending" criticisms. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2019/10/17/dentons-leader-fires-back-at-greenbergs-parochial-and-condescending-criticisms/)] * What Parks and Rec can teach us about court reporters. [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/parks-and-recreation-reminds-us-how-important-court-reporters-are-to-the-legal-system)] * Watchdog group says judge should be removed from the bench for being a harassing, misogynist prick. If only the Supreme Court worked that way. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1210509/ny-judge-should-be-fired-for-sexist-slurs-judicial-watchdog)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)

# Biglaw Firms Forced To Raise Salaries, Deliver Huge Bonuses Due To Hot Lateral Market
## Firms hope their big compensation packages will be enough to attract top talent.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 3, 2021 at 2:28 PMJune 3, 2021 at 1:22 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/biglaw-firms-forced-to-raise-salaries-deliver-huge-bonuses-due-to-hot-lateral-market/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Forced%20To%20Raise%20Salaries,%20Deliver%20Huge%20Bonuses%20Due%20To%20Hot%20Lateral%20Market)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/biglaw-firms-forced-to-raise-salaries-deliver-huge-bonuses-due-to-hot-lateral-market/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/biglaw-firms-forced-to-raise-salaries-deliver-huge-bonuses-due-to-hot-lateral-market/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We’re not seeing firms ask us for one or two associates. Some are coming to us saying we need 10.

The bonuses are more impacting the industry beyond the walls of what it typically has. This has broken that barrier. It has forced the hands of a lot of smaller markets to increase their compensation because in order to compete with talent, they have to compete with the big firms’ compensation because the firms are so much more willing to have people sit in other markets. Firms are being much more willing to pay what they need to pay in order to get really quality associates in the door.

— Summer Eberhard, West Coast-based managing director in the associate practice group at legal recruiter Major Lindsey & Africa, commenting on the [impact that special bonuses have had](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/lawyers-get-164-000-bonuses-to-keep-working-100-hours-a-week) on the associate lateral hiring market. Associates could receive [up to $164,000 in year-end and special bonus money](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/special-bonus-tracker-2021/) based on class year, on top of their already high salaries.

# Biglaw Recovery
## There can be a period of culture shock that new in-house counsel experience after leaving Biglaw.
By [Meyling "Mey" Ly Ortiz](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mortiz/)  
onFebruary 16, 2023 at 1:48 PMFebruary 16, 2023 at 11:50 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-recovery/&text=Biglaw%20Recovery)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-recovery/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-recovery/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Although I have been in-house for almost seven years, I can distinctly remember my “detoxification.” For those of you who are unaware of this phenomenon, allow me to enlighten you.

This is the period where recovering Biglaw lawyers may experience disorientation or dissociation during their transition into in-house life, especially if the cultures of their prior employer and new employer are vastly different. In other words, there can be a period of culture shock that new in-house counsel experience.

Here are a few of my unique experiences from my detoxification.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Losing My Skepticism Of Kindness

I vividly remember my first few weeks in-house and how everyone was so nice. People stopped what they were doing, got up out of their chairs with smiles that reached their eyes, and took the time to talk. They not only introduced themselves, but they also asked questions that they undoubtedly knew would extend the conversation (as if they genuinely wanted to get to know me).

And while we all know to say, “if you need anything, don’t hesitate to reach out,” they actually meant it — and even more astonishing to my jaded self — proactively shared resources about the team, department and company with me — unprompted.

This was not just a handful of nice people. It was everyone. And I didn’t know what to make of it. I kept thinking to myself, “What’s the catch?” “What’s their angle?” “Why is everyone so nice?”

###Sponsored

From Pilot and Above The Law

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
It took me awhile, but now I understand that my current company has an incredible culture — in stark contrast to the more transactional nature of firm life, where every unbillable nicety was something that had to be made up later.

Shedding Toxic Productivity

Speaking of which, I also clearly remember waking up in the middle of the night on one occasion that first week with a panicked thought that I had forgotten to bill. And during the first few weeks, I was anxious because without billing and without any work product like a brief or discovery to show, I wasn’t sure how to “prove” to my new boss that I had indeed been working.

I remember going to my manager and asking if she wanted me to send her a weekly email with what I worked on, because I used to send weekly or every-other-week updates to my former shareholders on the cases that I managed for them. I also asked for more projects. She declined, and reassured me that my plate would get full soon enough as people got to know me.

Something I have been unable to shed — checking my email right when I wake up and right before I go to bed. But I have learned to curb my need to immediately respond to emails — although I may have an occasional involuntary twitch.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Learning To Be Growth-Minded

Last, but certainly not least, part of my detoxification experience included learning to be growth-minded and not being a perfectionist. When you’re in-house and clients need immediacy, you can’t let perfect be the enemy of good enough. Without the blame/throw-someone-under-the-bus culture and CYA culture that can often exist at a law firm, I learned to get comfortable with taking risk and exercising judgment — without all the facts and data. I had to learn to let go of fear of failure and accept uncertainty and that if I made a mistake, we would address, learn and move on.

Tongue-in-cheek[[1]](#f1) aside, it personally took me six months to feel settled — and there were moments in those early six months that I wondered if I made the wrong decision leaving firm life and considered a relapse. But almost seven years later post-recovery, I’m glad I stuck it out through the detoxification period.

[ [1]](#reff1) Please note that this post intentionally uses hyperbole to make a comparison between the stereotype of a toxic Biglaw culture and in-house but I do not intend to make light of addiction or mental health conditions.

Meyling “Mey” Ly Ortiz is in-house at Toyota Motor North America. Her passions include mentoring, championing belonging, and a personal blog: TheMeybe.com. At home, you can find her doing her best to be a “fun” mom to a toddler and preschooler and chasing her best self on her Peloton. You can follow her on LinkedIn ([https://www.linkedin.com/in/meybe/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/meybe/)). And you knew this was coming: her opinions are hers alone.

# It's Been A Mad March, But Here's A Chance To Win $5,000
## Join Lateral Link’s bracket challenge for a chance to win.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onMarch 6, 2020 at 3:30 PMMarch 6, 2020 at 2:49 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/its-been-a-mad-march-but-heres-a-chance-to-win-5000/&text=It’s%20Been%20A%20Mad%20March,%20But%20Here’s%20A%20Chance%20To%20Win%20$5,000)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/its-been-a-mad-march-but-heres-a-chance-to-win-5000/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/its-been-a-mad-march-but-heres-a-chance-to-win-5000/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With the men’s college basketball tournament approaching, we are inviting our clients and candidates to join Lateral Link’s bracket challenge for a chance to win $5,000. Entry is free, all you have to do is [register](https://app.laterallink.com/register) on Lateral Link, [follow us on LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/company/lateral-link), and fill out your [bracket](http://laterallink.mayhem.cbssports.com/e/e53e4a69e7d39c0ddc373d082d0d0eb4bf5dbd0eb3f2487c?ttag=BPM20_cpy_invite_new). Before practicing at Am Law 200 firms, most of our recruiters attended top law schools, and had the chance to witness the trials and tribulations of their school’s team firsthand. Here are their thoughts on their school’s chances in the upcoming tournament. 

[Paul Dorfeld](https://www.laterallink.com/team/paul-dorfeld/) | The Ohio State University

When I came to Ohio State, the basketball program was fresh off NCAA sanctions under the previous head coach. Over the next decade-plus, Thad Matta revitalized the program, leading them to five conference crowns, four conference tournament titles, two final fours, and an NIT title. Current head coach Chris Holtmann has brought the program back the past three seasons and currently has them ranked in the top 20. The boys are poised for a run this March, so the Buckeyes are my sleeper pick!

[Jesse Hyde](https://www.laterallink.com/team/jesse-hyde) | University of Michigan and Loyola University Chicago School of Law

In 2018, my two alma maters squared off in the Final Four. I have enjoyed seeing the recent success of both programs and am particularly excited about Juan Howard being Michigan’s coach. He is an outstanding leader and next year’s recruiting class is stacked. Go Blue!

[Steven Rushing](https://www.laterallink.com/team/steven-rushing/) | Florida

Florida was never a basketball school. At least until winning back-to-back NCAA championships in ’06-’07. Being on campus for that incredible run made winning seem easy and we’re living and breathing off that feeling to this day. With only a championship able to quench that thirst, I’m hoping for a miracle run with our hot and cold team this March Madness.

[Scott Hodes](https://www.laterallink.com/team/scott-hodes) | Florida

I started at the University of Florida right after their Final Four run in 1993. Coach Billy Donovan took over soon thereafter and really put Florida basketball on the map. Since that time, they made history with back-to-back championships with arguably one of the best college basketball teams in recent memory, and Gator fans have grown accustomed to deep tournament runs. Although inconsistent as of late, they are not a team to be taken lightly come every March.

[Ryan Belville](https://www.laterallink.com/team/ryan-belville) | Michigan

Michigan basketball keeps me afloat during the, shall we say, somewhat lean football years as of late. Two final fours and an elite 8 in the last seven years is solid. Let’s see if we can make another deep run this year. 

[David Lat](https://www.laterallink.com/team/david-lat) | Harvard

I am probably the one person in America who does not follow March Madness, so I’m afraid I don’t have much to say about Harvard — and given their history in the tournament, I don’t think there’s much to be said. I’ll just quote the Harvard Lampoon from 2013, when the Crimson did surprisingly well: “America, we are sorry for messing up your brackets and also your financial system and everything else.”

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s ](http://bit.ly/2b4rW3j)team of expert contributors. [Michael Allen](https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelallen/) is the CEO of Lateral Link. He is based in the Los Angeles office and focuses exclusively on Partner and General Counsel placements for top firms and companies. Prior to founding Lateral Link in 2006, he worked as an attorney at both Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP and Irell & Manella LLP. Michael graduated summa cum laude from the University of California, San Diego before earning his JD, cum laude, from Harvard Law School.

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](https://www.laterallink.com/) to find out more about us.

# Top 10 Biglaw Firm Is Conducting 'Merits-Based' Reviews That Have Resulted In Job Cuts
## The line between layoffs and performance-based cuts is growing awfully 'blurry.'
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 19, 2023 at 11:16 AMApril 19, 2023 at 10:53 AM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/top-10-biglaw-firm-is-conducting-merits-based-reviews-that-have-resulted-in-job-cuts/&text=Top%2010%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Conducting%20‘Merits-Based’%20Reviews%20That%20Have%20Resulted%20In%20Job%20Cuts)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/top-10-biglaw-firm-is-conducting-merits-based-reviews-that-have-resulted-in-job-cuts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/top-10-biglaw-firm-is-conducting-merits-based-reviews-that-have-resulted-in-job-cuts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Springtime is upon us, and Biglaw firms seem to be doing their fair share of spring cleaning — i.e., conducting “performance reviews” that result in out-of-work associates. If that sounds like these firms are performing stealth layoffs, you may be right on the money based on past precedent.

One of the latest firms to make cuts is Ropes & Gray, which recently rose two places to No. 10 in the Am Law 100 by bringing in $2.718 billion gross revenue in 2022. (On the other hand, thanks to its successful recruitment strategies, the firm’s lawyer head count increased by 8.7%, which in turn caused its revenue per lawyer to drop by 6.5%.)

According to numerous message boards, Ropes recently made some attempts to slim down its associate ranks. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/04/13/in-response-to-layoff-chatter-ropes-gray-cites-merits-based-evaluation-process/) has the details:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[T]he firm said on Wednesday that any cuts result from a performance evaluation. The firm’s statement follows a Big Law trend this year of firms quietly making cuts through the review process.

“The quarterly performance management process is a part of the normal course [of] our business operations. We continue to use our same merits-based evaluation process,” the firm said in a statement provided by a spokesperson.

But how can you tell the difference between a stealth layoff and a genuine review-based termination these days? Industry experts say the line has become “increasingly blurry” in recent weeks. “All firms are engaged in a sort of rightsizing,” a consultant familiar with the New York market told Am Law. “Everyone is engaging in some process of looking at head count and so [using] these aggressive reviews.”

Best of luck to those who are being let go from Ropes & Gray.

If your firm or organization is reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs) or text us ([646-820-8477](tel:646-820-8477)).

# Orrick's New Partners: Diverse By Many Metrics
## Out of 18 new partners, 10 are diverse or women lawyers.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJanuary 18, 2017 at 6:55 PMJanuary 18, 2017 at 8:19 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/orricks-new-partners-diverse-by-many-metrics/&text=Orrick’s%20New%20Partners:%20Diverse%20By%20Many%20Metrics)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/orricks-new-partners-diverse-by-many-metrics/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/orricks-new-partners-diverse-by-many-metrics/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In the Biglaw annual calendar, what does January stand for? Some firms announce bonuses this month. Some lawyers, bonuses from last year in hand, make lateral moves. But perhaps the most notable thing about January is how it is, for most firms at least, the effective date of partnership for new partners.

In our [New Partner Watch](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/new-partner-watch/) feature, we’ve been writing about new partnership classes at selected firms. We tend to write about announcements that are, for one reason or another, interesting. For this current cycle, we’ve been focused on diversity (or the lack thereof) among new Biglaw partners. If you think you have a class that merits scrutiny, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=New%20Partner%20Watch) (subject line: “New Partner Watch”).

Today’s topic: the 18 new partners at [Orrick](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/orrick-herrington-sutcliffe/), which the firm just announced yesterday. From their [press release](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/orricks-new-partners-diverse-by-many-metrics/2) (posted in full on the next page):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Orrick announced today the admission of 18 lawyers to the firm’s partnership, effective January 1, 2017.

“We are thrilled to welcome these exceptional lawyers to our partnership,” said Orrick Chairman & CEO Mitch Zuklie. “This diverse team demonstrates our continued commitment to the technology, energy & infrastructure, and finance sectors, and to our powerhouse litigation and IP platform.”

Orrick’s 2017 partner class includes six tech-focused corporate partners, one energy & infrastructure partner and six finance partners. It includes five litigation partners, including two IP litigators. The new partners are based in eight U.S. offices, as well as in Paris and Düsseldorf. Eleven have spent their entire law firm careers with Orrick. Ten of the 18 are diverse or women lawyers.

Congratulations to these 18 new partners on grabbing the ultimate Biglaw brass ring, and congratulations to Orrick on the impressive diversity of its class. The new partners are diverse according to many metrics — by practice area, geography, racial or ethnic background, and gender.

There are six partners who are diverse in terms of race/ethnicity: Daniel Kim (Los Angeles), David Lin (San Francisco), Bola Oloko (New York), Cathy Lui (San Francisco), John Palmer (San Francisco), and Michael Yang (Silicon Valley). There are five women partners: Irma Foley (D.C.), Christine Reynolds (Portland), Alyssa Caridis (Los Angeles), Diane Lamarche (Paris), and Cathy Lui (San Francisco).

The wording of the Orrick announcement is worth noting as well. Firm chair Mitch Zuklie praises this “diverse team” of “exceptional lawyers,” and the announcement explicitly notes that 10 out of the 18 new partners are diverse or women lawyers.

[David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/) is the founder and managing editor of Above the Law and the author of [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](https://supremeambitions.com/reviews/). He previously worked as a federal prosecutor in Newark, New Jersey; a litigation associate at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. # Summer Associate Programs Canceled At Firms That Needed To Delay Merger Due To COVID-19 Outbreak
## This proposed combination is off to an incredibly rocky start.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 10, 2020 at 3:41 PMApril 10, 2020 at 2:42 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-canceled-at-firms-that-needed-to-delay-merger-due-to-covid-19-outbreak/&text=Summer%20Associate%20Programs%20Canceled%20At%20Firms%20That%20Needed%20To%20Delay%20Merger%20Due%20To%20COVID-19%20Outbreak)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-canceled-at-firms-that-needed-to-delay-merger-due-to-covid-19-outbreak/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-canceled-at-firms-that-needed-to-delay-merger-due-to-covid-19-outbreak/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

This decision arises out of our conclusion that, given current and expected conditions, we cannot provide for a meaningful summer experience that allows our students to perform to their full potential.

— a spokesperson for Pepper Hamilton, commenting on the firm’s recent decision to [cancel its summer associate program](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/pepper-hamilton-troutman-sanders-nix-summer-associate-programs) alongside that of its merger partner, Troutman Sanders. Both firms have extended full-time job offers to the affected law students who would have spent their summers at the firms, [offering “financial assistance” to them](https://www.businessinsider.com/two-big-law-firms-cancel-summer-associate-programs-2020-4) as well. The merger between Pepper Hamilton and Troutman Sanders is being [postponed](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-merger-postponed-due-to-unprecedented-coronavirus-challenges/) until July 1, 2020, due to the coronavirus.

# WilmerHale And The Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day Of Leaking Client Whistleblower Docs To The WSJ
## The one simple thing you can do right now to avoid ending up like the lawyers in this story.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 28, 2017 at 10:28 AMSeptember 28, 2017 at 1:34 PM
106
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/wilmerhale-and-the-terrible-horrible-no-good-very-bad-day-of-leaking-client-whistleblower-docs-to-the-wsj/&text=WilmerHale%20And%20The%20Terrible,%20Horrible,%20No%20Good,%20Very%20Bad%20Day%20Of%20Leaking%20Client%20Whistleblower%20Docs%20To%20The%20WSJ)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/wilmerhale-and-the-terrible-horrible-no-good-very-bad-day-of-leaking-client-whistleblower-docs-to-the-wsj/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/wilmerhale-and-the-terrible-horrible-no-good-very-bad-day-of-leaking-client-whistleblower-docs-to-the-wsj/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Handing a drink to the SEC. (via Kendall and Kylie/YouTube)

Did you know that Pepsico’s former general counsel Maura Smith initiated an internal investigation into allegations of financial misreporting and that the SEC is looking into her subsequent departure as a possible violation of whistleblower laws? We didn’t either until yesterday, when the Wall Street Journal [told the world about it](https://www.wsj.com/articles/departure-of-pepsico-lawyer-is-focus-of-sec-probe-1506504603?mod=e2tw) after accidentally receiving a privileged memo from WilmerHale.

So if you know a Wilmer attorney, give ’em a hug today.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The memo, discussing a subpoena Smith received, was sent to the Wall Street Journal in an email including a number of other attorneys working on the matter. Given the circumstances, it’s safe to say someone’s inline autocomplete got the better of them. For any attorneys using a mailbox with that feature… maybe turn it off. On the plus side, as an efficiency aid, it saves you a few seconds every day. On the downside, one day it’ll send privileged and potentially career-ending documents to the press. Weigh those out and do whatever you think is best. Don’t worry, you can continue this story after you [go into your mail preferences](http://accc.uic.edu/answer/how-do-i-disable-outlook-auto-complete-and-clear-cache).

Welcome back. Wilmer’s statement, as [reported by Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/09/27/wilmer-inadvertently-leaks-pepsi-client-secrets-to-wall-street-journal/), falls appropriately upon the sword:

We deeply regret that privileged documents were inadvertently emailed to a reporter at The Wall Street Journal. WilmerHale takes full responsibility, and we apologize to our client. We promptly advised The Wall Street Journal of the error and asked the reporter to delete the material. The reporter told us he had deleted the material, but we later learned he had printed and retained hard copies.

We are disappointed that The Journal has decided to publish private information it knew was protected by our client’s legal privilege. We are taking additional measures designed to ensure that emails are not misaddressed to unintended recipients.

Is it just me, or does this measured professionalism come across as hopelessly archaic? Perhaps the real takeaway from all this for Wilmer should be the need for new public relations personnel. It’s 2017! A technological screw-up like this can’t be explained away with words like “inadvertently.” Here’s some free P.R. advice for Wilmer in case this comes up again:

# The U.S. Cities Where Biglaw Associates Are The Most Satisfied (2022)
## How did your firm do in this city-by-city ranking?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 15, 2022 at 12:29 PMAugust 15, 2022 at 11:59 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/the-u-s-cities-where-biglaw-associates-are-the-most-satisfied-2022/&text=The%20U.S.%20Cities%20Where%20Biglaw%20Associates%20Are%20The%20Most%20Satisfied%20(2022))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/the-u-s-cities-where-biglaw-associates-are-the-most-satisfied-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/the-u-s-cities-where-biglaw-associates-are-the-most-satisfied-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘We love our firm!’

Here at Above the Law, we’ve spent the past week or two discussing what makes Biglaw associates satisfied with their jobs. From their compensation to their firm’s commitment to their career development to their interaction with partners, there’s a whole lot at play when it comes to keeping associates happy and fulfilled professionally. But where in the U.S. are midlevel associates the most satisfied, and which firms are doing the best in each major market? Of course there’s a ranking for that, so let’s dig in.

As part of the American Lawyer’s Midlevel Associates Survey, firms were assessed on several aspects of job satisfaction and graded on a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 being the highest score. For the city-by-city satisfaction ranking, firms were rated by location, listing which associates are most satisfied across a particular city. As noted by Am Law, a change in location could mean a world of difference when it comes to professional happiness.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[A] lawyer’s experience at a firm can vary wildly depending on the practice they are in, the partner they work for or the office where they practice. A satellite office may offer a different experience than a headquarters, a full-service office may offer a different feel than one that houses only a few practices. …

[A]s the various city rankings will show, firms don’t always do well across all of their locales.

So, where can we find the most satisfied midlevels? It may be time for lawyers to giddyap and head down south, because it looks like they’re the happiest in Dallas, Texas, where the average satisfaction sore for the city was a 4.557. Here are the rest of the cities, in order of overall satisfaction.

- Dallas, TX: 4.557
- Salt Lake City, UT: 4.538
- Philadelphia, PA: 4.467
- Palo Alto, CA: 4.444
- Denver, CO: 4.439
- Houston, TX: 4.433
- San Francisco, CA: 4.405
- Atlanta, GA: 4.389
- Los Angeles, CA: 4.382
- New York, NY: 4.368
- Chicago, IL: 4.356
- Boston, MA: 4.350
- Washington, D.C.: 4.329
- Charlotte, NC: 4.298
- Miami, FL: 4.205
Associates in some of the most major markets of all are the least satisfied, with Miami coming in last place for midlevel satisfaction. And here we thought the city was [becoming “Wall Street south”](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/miami-is-bringing-the-heat-for-biglaw-firms/) (but by the looks of it, associates in “Wall Street north” aren’t that satisfied, either).

That leads us to our final question: at what firms are midlevels the most satisfied in each city? Let’s find out. We’ll use the same order as above, so you can see where associates are truly the most satisfied across firms.

- Dallas, TX: Kirkland (4.785)
- Salt Lake City, UT: Kirkland (4.782)
- Philadelphia, PA: Dechert (4.648)
- Palo Alto, CA: Morrison & Foerster (4.799)
- Denver, CO: Gibson Dunn (4.667)
- Houston, TX: Gibson Dunn (4.833)
- San Francisco, CA: O’Melveny & Myers (4.854)
- Atlanta, GA: Baker & Hostetler (4.833)
- Los Angeles, CA: Baker & Hostetler (4.983)
- New York, NY: Blank Rome (4.850)
- Chicago, IL: McDermott (4.774)
- Boston, MA: Morgan Lewis (4.790)
- Washington, D.C.: O’Melveny & Myers (4.926)
- Charlotte, NC: Dechert (4.475)
- Miami, FL: Greenberg Traurig (4.470)
Click [here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/08/12/the-2022-midlevel-associates-survey-city-by-city-rankings/) to see how other firms did in the ranking.

Did your firm make the cut? Do you agree with these satisfaction rankings by city? Please let us know what you think. You can email us at [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) or send a text at (646) 820-8477. Thanks so much.

# UK Biglaw Partners Have Thoughts About The US Biglaw Salary Wars -- None Of Them Good
## Tell us how you really feel.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 8, 2022 at 5:17 PMFebruary 8, 2022 at 3:46 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/uk-biglaw-partners-have-thoughts-about-the-us-biglaw-salary-wars-none-of-them-good/&text=UK%20Biglaw%20Partners%20Have%20Thoughts%20About%20The%20US%20Biglaw%20Salary%20Wars%20—%20None%20Of%20Them%20Good)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/uk-biglaw-partners-have-thoughts-about-the-us-biglaw-salary-wars-none-of-them-good/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/uk-biglaw-partners-have-thoughts-about-the-us-biglaw-salary-wars-none-of-them-good/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The market has been subverted by uber-aggressive U.S. firms, to no-one’s benefit.

— A rather critical response given by a Biglaw partner in the UK when asked about associate salaries in a survey published by [Law.com International](https://www.law.com/international-edition/2022/02/07/almost-all-law-firm-partners-think-their-nqs-earn-too-much/). According to that survey, 95% of respondents believe that salaries for junior lawyers are now too high, and 84% of respondents said they felt negative about the most recent round of raises. Only 5% felt positive about Milbank’s latest round of salary increases.

# A Short Defense Of Jones Day
## Yeah, yeah: Some folks at Jones Day worked for Trump.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onAugust 29, 2022 at 11:26 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/a-short-defense-of-jones-day/&text=A%20Short%20Defense%20Of%20Jones%20Day)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/a-short-defense-of-jones-day/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/a-short-defense-of-jones-day/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

I really don’t do this. Really.

I worked at Jones Day for 20 years, 17 as a partner. I was perfectly happy there. In 2009, I was offered an in-house job that I couldn’t resist, and I left the joint on good terms. I don’t think I’ve mentioned Jones Day in writing since, in what is now approaching 700 columns here at Above the Law. But it’s time to break my silence: The [New York Times went overboard](https://www.blogger.com/blog/post/edit/4454944101251496/7325986265427203525#) with its criticism this week.

Yeah, yeah: Some folks at Jones Day worked for Trump. Yeah, yeah: All right-thinking liberals — and, after January 6, to my eye, all right-thinking individuals — believe that Trump’s a scumbag. I certainly have been doing nothing in this column to curry favor with the possible next Trump administration. Here’s my final “yeah, yeah”: Some of the lawyers who worked in the Trump administration later returned to Jones Day.

I have this to say about all of that: Jones Day has about 2,500 lawyers. How many of those 2,500 worked on Trump stuff? 20? 30? 50? I can’t believe it was more than that; 50 lawyers staffs up an awful lot of big projects.

So what’s the average schlub partner in the Cleveland, or Los Angeles, or London office of Jones Day thinking about while those 50-ish lawyers are off doing their Trump things? “That Trump stuff might be a little offensive to me, but I’ve got other things to worry about — like tending to big corporate litigation or mergers and acquisitions.” The average Joe knows that the firm is playing its silly political games — the folks in D.C. always do — but that Joe is preoccupied with doing the things that busy lawyers do.

Moreover, be honest: Most of you would have an extraordinarily hard time turning down a high-ranking government job, even if the job were offered by an administration of which you were skeptical. (Think of the many arguments with which you disagreed that you’ve advanced in court for your clients.) One Jones Day partner agreed to serve as solicitor general under Trump. Solicitor general is an extraordinarily cool job; it permits you to represent the United States in the most interesting constitutional disputes of our time, assisted by the bevy of former Supreme Court clerks who work as assistants to the SG. Moreover, the job is generally not political — Dean Erwin Griswold worked at Jones Day after serving as the solicitor general in both the Johnson and Nixon administrations, so politics is obviously not dispositive.

I’m sure that a few of you — working at stridently liberal plaintiffs’-side firms and untempted by intellectual intrigue or resume-padding — would turn down the job of SG if offered it by a Republican administration. But I bet that most readers of this column would wrestle briefly with their consciences and then respond to the job offer with a hearty, “Hell, yeah; I accept!”

So, too, for serving as White House counsel. That must be a fascinating job. Most of it would not be political. You’d have hugely talented help — again, the staff is basically former Supreme Court clerks. And you’d be worth a fortune after acting in that capacity. If offered the job early in the Trump administration — before January 6 — how many of you would honestly have turned it down?

My argument is admittedly less convincing for jobs lower down in the governmental hierarchy. The jobs are less interesting as you move down the ladder, and your stomach might turn a bit more at the thought of helping someone with whom you disagree politically. But I bet many readers of this column insist that they’d never take a high-ranking government job, secure in the knowledge that there’s no chance they’d ever be offered one.

Finally, as weird as it sounds, Jones Day as a firm actually leans Democratic. In the 2020 federal elections, 86% of donations from Jones Day lawyers went to Democrats; in 2016, Jones Day lawyers donated $284,675 to Clinton and $7,622 to Trump. That’s no surprise — Jones Day lawyers by definition have post-graduate degrees; they’re not exactly cut from the less-educated mold that constitutes Trump’s base.

Could one be slightly offended by some of the choices that certain Jones Day lawyers made in the past six years? Maybe. But, so far as I know, no one from Jones Day has lost their license or is yet headed to jail on Trump’s behalf.

And the vast majority of the joint are merely lawyers being lawyers, only vaguely conscious of, and completely unaffected by, the political intrigues of the active few in D.C.

Let the nasty emails begin.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](https://www.amazon.com/Curmudgeons-Guide-Practicing-Law/dp/1641054336/ref=pd_lpo_14_t_0/144-3788773-6854967?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=1641054336&pd_rd_r=61f38502-781d-47fb-a260-1970deea4a4d&pd_rd_w=AWqCy&pd_rd_wg=kFTh8&pf_rd_p=7b36d496-f366-4631-94d3-61b87b52511b&pf_rd_r=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB&psc=1&refRID=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB) and [Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strateg](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0)[y](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# This Biglaw Firm Is Doing A Pretty Good Job Making Women Equity Partners
## Doing the best -- though there's still work to be done.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 16, 2021 at 5:48 PMSeptember 16, 2021 at 3:42 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/this-biglaw-firm-is-doing-a-pretty-good-job-making-women-equity-partners/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Doing%20A%20Pretty%20Good%20Job%20Making%20Women%20Equity%20Partners)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/this-biglaw-firm-is-doing-a-pretty-good-job-making-women-equity-partners/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/this-biglaw-firm-is-doing-a-pretty-good-job-making-women-equity-partners/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According the Law360’s Glass Ceiling Report, which Biglaw firm — with 601+ attorneys — has the highest percentage of women equity partners?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Hint: The firm’s equity partnership is 32.3 percent women. Though it should be noted women make up more than half of law school students and have been at over 40 percent for decades, so still there’s plenty of room for improvement.

# Biglaw Partner Named Special Counsel In Russia Investigation
## Yuge news.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 17, 2017 at 6:34 PMMay 17, 2017 at 6:43 PM
74
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-partner-named-special-counsel-in-russia-investigation/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Named%20Special%20Counsel%20In%20Russia%20Investigation)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-partner-named-special-counsel-in-russia-investigation/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/biglaw-partner-named-special-counsel-in-russia-investigation/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Robert Mueller

Big news. Yuge. In a letter [obtained by CNN](http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/17/politics/special-counsel-robert-mueller/index.html), the Deputy Attorney General, Rod Rosenstein, has appointed former FBI Director Robert Mueller as special counsel to shepherd the investigation into the possible interference by Russia into the 2016 presidential election.

Mueller has a sterling reputation in law enforcement. He led the FBI for 12 years and has previous public service including as United States Attorney for the Northern District of California and acting United States Attorney for the District of Massachusetts. He’s been appointed by both Republican and Democratic presidents for those positions.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Prior to his appointment as special counsel, Mueller was a partner at WilmerHale. He has now resigned from the firm to focus on the investigation. Which, given [the firm’s](http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/ivanka-trump-lawyer-jamie-gorelick-clintons-236445) [representation](http://www.businessinsider.com/jared-kushner-role-trump-white-house-2017-1) of Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, is probably for the best. [While at the firm](https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:uxzhLY3awr8J:https://www.wilmerhale.com/robert_mueller/+&cd=18&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us) his practice focused on investigations, crisis management, privacy and, perhaps most importantly for this particular assignment, cybersecurity work.

[Special counsel appointed in Russia probe](http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/17/politics/special-counsel-robert-mueller/index.html) [CNN]

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Black Biglaw Partner Shares Somber Thoughts Following Death Of George Floyd
## 'It could have been me,' he said.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 3, 2020 at 5:17 PMJune 3, 2020 at 2:28 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/black-biglaw-partner-shares-somber-thoughts-following-death-of-george-floyd/&text=Black%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Shares%20Somber%20Thoughts%20Following%20Death%20Of%20George%20Floyd)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/black-biglaw-partner-shares-somber-thoughts-following-death-of-george-floyd/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/black-biglaw-partner-shares-somber-thoughts-following-death-of-george-floyd/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The reality is that no matter what level of success you achieve, whether it’s a partner of a firm, a justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, it doesn’t matter. The treatment isn’t fair and equal. It isn’t our reality. When I looked at George Floyd pleading for his life, it carried the baggage I’ve carried with my entire life. It could have been me. It could have been my nephew; it could have been my cousin.

— [Robert Simpson](https://www.carltonfields.com/team/s/robert-r-simpson), a partner at Carlton Fields, reflecting on his thoughts after [watching the video of George Floyd’s death](https://www.law.com/2020/06/03/it-could-have-been-me-black-attorneys-reflect-on-george-floyds-death-and-what-comes-next/) under the knee of a police officer.

# Elite Biglaw Firm Is Offering Extra Special Bonuses On Top Of Regular Bonuses
## This Am Law Top 10 firm is spreading the love -- with money!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 4, 2020 at 11:11 AMDecember 4, 2020 at 11:04 AM
25
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/elite-biglaw-firm-is-offering-extra-special-bonuses-on-top-of-regular-bonuses/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Offering%20Extra%20Special%20Bonuses%20On%20Top%20Of%20Regular%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/elite-biglaw-firm-is-offering-extra-special-bonuses-on-top-of-regular-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/elite-biglaw-firm-is-offering-extra-special-bonuses-on-top-of-regular-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Associates, did you click on this hoping for some firm to beat the Cravath bonus scale? Temper your greed — and think about your colleagues on the staff side.

Ever since Biglaw bonus season started, we’ve received a slew of emails from law firm support staff wondering what their fate may be as the Benjamins continue to rain down upon associates. After all, it takes an army for law firms this large to run, and the behind-the-scenes battalions of staff members deserve their due, too.

After an extremely successful year, despite the ongoing pandemic, one of the most prestigious firms in the country came to the conclusion that its worldwide support staff — a class defined as business services and legal services employees who don’t participate in its legal bonus scheme — deserved a little bit more during COVID times, and decided to issue special bonuses to them of $1,500, on top of any year-end bonuses they were already due to receive. (Sources tell us these bonuses can be up to 20 percent of annual salary for the highest performers.)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Congratulations to White & Case for showing their staff members some appreciation during these tough times. “I am immensely proud of the role that each of you have played in contributing to our success, and the way in which we have risen to the challenges presented by the pandemic,” writes White & Case chief operating officer Greg Dolan. Staffers at the firm are quite pleased:

It was a very pleasant surprise! And nice to know that our firm’s support for its business services employees isn’t just lip service.

Add this to the fact that we haven’t faced any layoffs or salary reductions at White & Case this year, it makes it a great place to work for lawyers and non-lawyers alike!

Staff bonuses at White & Case will be paid sometime in December. Congrats to all!

# Should Law Firms Ban Or Embrace Generative AI?
## Eliminating generative AI from your firm’s toolkit increases your firm’s risk of falling behind in efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and innovation.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onAugust 21, 2023 at 10:45 AMAugust 21, 2023 at 10:49 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/should-law-firms-ban-or-embrace-generative-ai/&text=Should%20Law%20Firms%20Ban%20Or%20Embrace%20Generative%20AI?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/should-law-firms-ban-or-embrace-generative-ai/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/should-law-firms-ban-or-embrace-generative-ai/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“We completely outlawed the use of ChatGPT in our firm,” a law firm partner recently told me. 

“How’s that working for you?” I asked. 

“Our lawyers are probably among the most adept generative AI users around,” he shrugged. 

Firms may monitor online traffic and prohibit lawyers from visiting specific domains on office computers. But lawyers can, and will, still experiment with generative AI on their personal devices and at home. 

Some may even use tools like ChatGPT for legal work without telling anyone. They could divulge confidential client information and make important decisions relying solely on AI analysis without you ever knowing.

Its unenforceability alone highlights the short-sightedness of a total ban on generative AI. Instead, law firms can benefit by carefully crafting a use policy to monitor and guide lawyers. Here’s why and how it works.

Bans Overlook The Many Benefits AI Offers

Banning generative AI outright may seem like a straightforward way to prevent the attendant ethical and legal issues. But generative AI can create content, draft and summarize documents, and perform tasks with stunning speed and impressive accuracy. Leveraging generative AI can save lawyers significant time and resources while helping to produce high-quality legal work at lower costs.

Eliminating generative AI from your firm’s toolkit increases your firm’s risk of falling behind in efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and innovation. A ban also ignores the reality that clients increasingly expect lawyers to use technology to better serve their needs. Seven in 10 in-house counsel [recently surveyed](https://www.lexisnexis.co.uk/research-and-reports/generative-ai-and-the-legal-profession-report.html) expect their law firms to use cutting-edge technology, including generative AI tools. Waiting too long or failing to do so could harm your firm’s ability to remain relevant. 

Plus, bans drive AI use underground, in the dark, where it can be misused. It’s better to foster a culture that values and promotes the responsible use of AI. A good AI use policy helps lawyers understand how and when to use generative AI to minimize risk and maximize value. 

What makes a good AI use policy?

A comprehensive AI use policy can help provide much-needed guidance to lawyers and staff. It ensures legal professionals deploy and use AI solutions ethically and transparently and fosters an open environment for discussing ethical quandaries, expressing concerns, and reporting difficulties with AI systems. Such a policy may:

- Clearly define the scope of use of generative AI applications in the firm. 
- Establish requirements for data privacy and client confidentiality. 
- Encourage discussions with clients about the use of AI in their cases. 
- Require lawyer and staff training on generative AI best practices and ethical considerations.
As the AI field moves quickly, it makes sense to designate a “policy owner” to keep abreast of technological advancements and regularly update the policy as needed. [Many resources are available](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/ongoing-ai-education-strategies-and-resources-for-lawyers/) to help lawyers and firms understand AI and how to use it ethically and responsibly.

A Well-Crafted AI Policy Is An Empowerment Tool

A well-crafted generative AI use policy ensures your firm’s legal professionals know the ethical guidelines surrounding AI usage, including the potential risks and consequences. Its guidance encourages legal professionals to develop and sharpen their technical skills and readily adapt to change — the type of skills and abilities needed to compete in the future.

Your policy will encourage compliance with legal and ethical requirements and foster a culture of competence and integrity. Trained and knowledgeable AI users are better equipped to make conscientious decisions grounded in innovative thinking. Embrace a policy-driven approach to harness the benefits of generative AI while maintaining the highest level of professionalism and adherence to ethical standards.

Olga V. Mack is the VP at [LexisNexis](https://www.lexisnexis.com/) and CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407), [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G), and  [Blockchain Value: Transforming Business Models, Society, and Communities](https://www.amazon.com/Blockchain-Value-Transforming-Business-Communities/dp/1952538246). She is working on Visual IQ for Lawyers, her next book (ABA 2023). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Biglaw Firm Awards Special Bonuses And Expands Bonus Pool For Extra Valuable Associates
## Of course the firm re-upped bonuses when the market moved.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 8, 2021 at 10:30 AMDecember 8, 2021 at 10:14 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/fried-frank-special-bonuses-21/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Awards%20Special%20Bonuses%20And%20Expands%20Bonus%20Pool%20For%20Extra%20Valuable%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/fried-frank-special-bonuses-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/fried-frank-special-bonuses-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Bonus season is upon us and Biglaw is busy giving out lots of money to the associates who make the firms tick.

As you may recall, Fried Frank was already pretty quick on the bonus draw, announcing year-end bonuses that matched the Cravath scale[ way back on November 24th](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/fried-frank-bonus/). But now that[ Davis Polk has moved the goal posts](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/davis-polk-bonuses-21/) via new special bonuses, well another bonus memo is in order for the firm (ranked 60th on the Am Law 100 with $780,300,000 in gross revenue in 2020).

Yesterday, the firm announced special bonuses on that Davis Polk scale:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  


But as an extra kicker, the firm, which previously announced additional bonuses for “extraordinary efforts,” is bumping up the size of that pool, from $2,250 – $30,000 to $3,000 to $34,500.

As you know, the Firm has had a long-standing commitment to rewarding the extraordinary efforts of its attorneys by paying premiums of 15% or 30% above the market bonus amounts for attorneys who meet the criteria specified in our year-end bonus policies. As an update to the Firm’s 2021 Year-End Bonus Policy, the 15% and 30% premiums will be applied to the 2021 bonus scale announced on November 24, so that premium amounts will range from $3,000 to $34,500. For example, an associate in the class of 2014 is eligible to receive a maximum year-end bonus of $149,500, plus special bonuses totaling a maximum of $87,000.

Congratulations to everyone at the firm!

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her.
