# Biglaw Associate On Trial For Punching Man After Alleged Homophobic Slur
## He says he acted in self-defense.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 11, 2023 at 3:18 PMSeptember 18, 2023 at 11:52 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-associate-on-trial-for-punching-man-after-alleged-homophobic-slur/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20On%20Trial%20For%20Punching%20Man%20After%20Alleged%20Homophobic%20Slur)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-associate-on-trial-for-punching-man-after-alleged-homophobic-slur/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-associate-on-trial-for-punching-man-after-alleged-homophobic-slur/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Barney Gush, an associate in the Real Estate Disputes practice in the London office of Eversheds Sutherland, is facing charges of inflicting grievous bodily harm after a September 2021 night out. He’s accused of fracturing the jaw of investment banker, Jonathan Luke, but Gush contends he only did so after he was called a homophobic slur at a London bar.

As[ reported by](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/eversheds-sutherland-lawyer-punched-banker-over-alleged-homophobic-slur) RollOnFriday, Luke says he was “reasonably tipsy” at the time of the incident:

“I was with colleagues and having a nice time and I remember feeling this punch at the bottom of my jaw from the right. It felt like a big, sudden impact, a shock,” Luke told the court. “I was not braced for any impact and it was very sore. I felt a bit of a hole in my mouth and it was where the jaw had displaced.”

Luke said he hoped he could sleep it off, but went to A&E in the morning. “I could not swallow and two metal plates were put in to crack the lower jaw back into place,” he said.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Gush, through his attorney, Aisling Byrnes, paints a different picture, saying Luke was “very drunk” and he was “making a little bit of a nuisance” of himself on the dance floor:

Gush claims that the banker shouted the gay slur: “F*** off you little p***,” due to his flamboyant dancing at the bar. Luke denies making the homophobic slur.

Byrnes said that while it is not disputed that Gush hit Luke, the banker had “made physical contact” with Gush while he was dancing. “He and his friend moved away and you backed into him harder than before while he was dancing,” Byrnes put it to Luke.

According to Gush, he asked Luke why he kept bumping into him and told him to leave him alone. But Luke insisted: “I didn’t really bump into anyone.”

Prosecutors have disputed Gush’s story, saying Luke “did not commit any act of violence” and “nothing justified the defendant punching him in the face with such force.” But Gush insists he acted in self-defense, and Luke moved towards him with his arm at “neck and chest height.”

The trial is ongoing.

# For The Love Of All That Is Holy, Stop Blaming ChatGPT For This Bad Brief
## Generative AI isn't the one who filed that affirmation with the court, so stop bagging on it.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 30, 2023 at 11:14 AMMay 30, 2023 at 12:59 PM
25
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/chatgpt-bad-lawyering/&text=For%20The%20Love%20Of%20All%20That%20Is%20Holy,%20Stop%20Blaming%20ChatGPT%20For%20This%20Bad%20Brief)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/chatgpt-bad-lawyering/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/chatgpt-bad-lawyering/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“Here’s What Happens When Your Lawyer Uses ChatGPT,” blasted the [New York Times headline](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/27/nyregion/avianca-airline-lawsuit-chatgpt.html) to the delight of tech skeptic lawyers everywhere. A seemingly quite irate Judge Kevin Castel of the Southern District of New York issued [a show cause order](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2023/05/Show-Cause.pdf) directed at the law firm of Levidow, Levidow & Oberman and its attorneys Peter LoDuca and Steven Schwartz asking why he shouldn’t impose sanctions after a number of cases in the firm’s recent filing turned out to be made up — another of [ChatGPT’s well-documented court case hallucinations](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/chatgpt-crowns-clarence-thomas-as-champion-of-gay-rights-in-feedback-loop-of-stupid/).

An airline defendant filed a motion to dismiss a personal injury claim that had wound its way into federal court. The case belonged to Schwartz, but after it was removed to federal court, LoDuca became counsel of record and [filed the response to the motion to dismiss](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2023/05/GPT-Brief.pdf) under his name. It deals with a lot of thorny issues — competing statutes of limitations, the Bankruptcy Code, international treaties — but the response managed to find on-point citations for every procedural hurdle. Pretty compelling stuff!

The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit specifically addresses the effect of a bankruptcy stay under the Montreal Convention in the case of Varghese v. China Southern Airlines Co.. Ltd., 925 F.3d 1339 (11th Cir. 2019), stating “Appellants argue that the district court erred in dismissing their claims as untimely. They assert that the limitations period under the Montreal Convention was tolled during the pendency of the Bankruptcy Court proceedings. We agree. The Bankruptcy Code provides that the filing of a bankruptcy petition operates as a stay of proceedings against the debtor that were or could have been commenced before the bankruptcy case was filed. 11 U.S.C. § 362(a)….

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
And the purported quote from the Eleventh Circuit detailing the precise result plaintiff sought under the precise instance of bankruptcy impaired, Montreal Convention statute of limitations goes on with multiple internal citations for another half a page.

Unfortunately, this case doesn’t exist. And some of the internal citations don’t either. Perhaps finding a whole page of directly quotable support for a hyperspecific legal question should’ve tipped someone off?

Schwartz had asked the buzzy AI application to give him a research assist, unaware that those of us covering generative AI have [flagged its propensity to flagrantly make stuff up to please its user](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/the-legal-industry-has-a-long-way-to-go-before-gpt-matches-the-talk/). And it’s very, very confident in its output regardless of its ability to back it up, which is why the epithet “Mansplaining as a Service” rings so true. That’s also why the conversation among the tech savvy has advanced from what generative AI can accomplish to [how do you put ethical and professional guardrails on this thing](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/casetext-cocounsel-ai-tool/)?

But while the media — and the social media zeitgeist — spent the weekend ripping ChatGPT, this isn’t about generative AI. They can chase the clicks with their GPT headlines, but this is a simple lawyering story.

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This isn’t any different than turning in a brief with red-flagged cases or just slapping the first 10 results from a database search into the filing and calling it a day. The problem wasn’t the search that ChatGPT produced, it was the lawyer failing to bother to read the full opinions in the cases he chose to cite.

That’s why I’m not really buying the Schwartz defense that he had never really used the app and “therefore was unaware of the possibility that its content could be false.” It doesn’t matter if the results were right or wrong, you still have to read the frickin’ opinions! Back in the day, a Westlaw or Lexis search would rarely turn up the right result on a lawyer’s first stab at it — and you had to check to make sure the opinion really was useful.

Adding generative AI to the mix of research tools doesn’t alter that calculus. It just — when deployed with the right protections — reduces the number of tries an attorney will need to get the right cases. That’s going to make a significant improvement in the accuracy and efficiency of lawyering. But it’s not replacing the attorney.

Don’t blame AI for lawyering fails. Like a lot of things in tech, the source of the error here lies between the keyboard and the chair.

[Here’s What Happens When Your Lawyer Uses ChatGPT](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/27/nyregion/avianca-airline-lawsuit-chatgpt.html) [New York Times]

# Am Law 100 Firm Offers ZERO Year-End Bonus 'Without Any Acknowledgement'
## 'A Real Life National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation.'
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 3, 2024 at 11:17 AMJanuary 3, 2024 at 11:05 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-zero-year-end-bonus-without-any-acknowledgement/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Offers%20ZERO%20Year-End%20Bonus%20‘Without%20Any%20Acknowledgement’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-zero-year-end-bonus-without-any-acknowledgement/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-zero-year-end-bonus-without-any-acknowledgement/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
At the end of 2022, Cozen O’Connor left its attorneys fuming when it [issued “special” bonuses far below the market standard](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/cozen-special-bonus-2022/). At the time, we wrote that “at least they’re getting bonuses at all….” That proved darkly prophetic as 2023 came to a close and associates have realized there aren’t going to be bonuses at all.

The AmLaw100 firm Cozen O’Connor gave no year-end bonuses this year. This is shocking given the consistent year-end bonuses, and even special bonuses, over the past few years. There is major dissension among the associates right now. Is the firm in trouble?

The frustration isn’t limited to bonuses, as the perennially below-market firm sent around an email about salaries that left attorneys flat:

After a thorough review and analysis, we are pleased to announce that starting salaries for the 2024 class will be increased by between $10,000 and $15,000. Nothing will change in our compensation process for existing attorneys.

In other words, the firm is making an adjustment to protect its law school recruiting but doing nothing for attorneys already on staff. And, for some unknown reason, sent this to the attorneys who aren’t the class of 2024. Everyone else has to wait to see if they get any adjustment to match their peers at other firms.

We will reflect our new compensation structure in compensation adjustments made during the normal compensation process in Feb/March 2024 (retroactive to January 1, 2014).

Presumably January 1, 2024.

But back to bonuses. Last cycle, the firm explained that, despite a profitable 2022, they had to pinch pennies over fears that 2023 would present economic headwinds. Fast forward, and Cozen leadership has consistently boasted a strong 2023 to its team. Yet not only has there been no talk of making lawyers whole based on last year’s cuts, there aren’t any bonuses this year.

And associates report receiving no warning that they’d be going into the holidays empty-handed.

Cozen O’Connor has lapsed into a real life National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation. Every year, without fail, firm offered a bonus at the end of the year that was not merit based but universally offered. Above the Law covered it last year. Without any acknowledgement, the firm has not given the bonus this year. Attorneys have been left in the dark completely. Many were of course relying on it. This has enraged countless attorneys. 

Reportedly, counsel are also not getting bonuses, but at least they were warned that this was coming.

Law firm “bonuses” aren’t so much “bonuses” as a “variable salary tier.” No one knows at the beginning of the year exactly how much the bonus gods (read: Cravath) will bestow upon the market, but, like Clark Griswold, associates still count on it as part of their salary. To yank it without warning just… well…

Clark: I was expecting a check. Instead I got enrolled in a jelly club. 17 years with the company. I’ve gotten a Christmas bonus every year but this one. You don’t want to give bonuses, fine. But when people count on them as their salary, well what you did just plain…

Rusty Griswold: Sucks.

Comp memo on the next page.

Please help us help you when it comes to salary news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Salary) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Salary”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# These Biglaw Salary Raises Were 'Inevitable,' So When Will The First Firm Match?
## Making more money in Biglaw is just like Thanos.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 20, 2022 at 12:27 PMJanuary 20, 2022 at 12:11 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/these-biglaw-salary-raises-were-inevitable-so-when-will-the-first-firm-match/&text=These%20Biglaw%20Salary%20Raises%20Were%20‘Inevitable,’%20So%20When%20Will%20The%20First%20Firm%20Match?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/these-biglaw-salary-raises-were-inevitable-so-when-will-the-first-firm-match/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/these-biglaw-salary-raises-were-inevitable-so-when-will-the-first-firm-match/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It was only a matter of time. This was inevitable. Others will follow.

If you could see in to the offices of managing partners and chairs at other firms across the US today, you’d observe a lot of eye-rolling and head shaking about this announcement.

It advances an arms race that most firms don’t want to advance. But it was inevitable given a perfect storm of low expenses and very high performance by many firms for several years in a row leading a large group to be flush with cash to invest in talent in a tight talent market.

— [Kent Zimmermann](https://www.consultzg.com/people/kent-zimmermann/), a partner at legal consultancy Zeughauser Group, offering his thoughts on the latest round of [salary raises that were announced by Milbank](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/alert-milbank-announces-salary-scale-increases-to-kick-off-the-new-year/) earlier today. Wait and watch along with us as the Biglaw salary scale begins to rise once again.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# How Did Reproductive Rights Group Get Mixed Up With Attorneys Making Anti-Abortion Donations?
## A lesson in how legal needs to be considered part of a unified entity.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 12, 2022 at 2:14 PMSeptember 12, 2022 at 2:01 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-did-reproductive-rights-group-get-mixed-up-with-attorneys-making-anti-abortion-donations/&text=How%20Did%20Reproductive%20Rights%20Group%20Get%20Mixed%20Up%20With%20Attorneys%20Making%20Anti-Abortion%20Donations?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-did-reproductive-rights-group-get-mixed-up-with-attorneys-making-anti-abortion-donations/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-did-reproductive-rights-group-get-mixed-up-with-attorneys-making-anti-abortion-donations/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Clients and lawyers don’t necessarily have to see eye-to-eye on everything. But when you’re a political think tank raising money from donors to advance a cause, maybe funneling those donations to a law firm with a PAC funding the other side is… ill-advised.

That’s what appears to be happening at the Guttmacher Institute, a high-profile reproductive rights think tank, that’s presently signing checks to Jackson Lewis. Unfortunately, [Jackson Lewis passes some of that money along to anti-abortion candidates](https://jezebel.com/leading-abortion-research-group-employs-law-firm-that-g-1849518992) through its affiliated PAC. Guttmacher Employees United, the group’s unionized employees, have called on their bosses to sever its ties with the firm.

Cynics will point out that dropping Jackson Lewis would inure to the benefit of the union, since the pro-employer firm represents Guttmacher Institute in contract negotiations. But this is a red herring. Guttmacher could easily replace Jackson Lewis with any number of the talented anti-union law firms out there. That’s not a knock on Jackson Lewis, whose credentials in this area are well known, but they aren’t the only anti-union firm in the sea. This is less about an imagined tactical advantage and all about calling out an advocacy group for putting its money where its mouth isn’t.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
And, of course, Jackson Lewis isn’t only giving to anti-abortion politicians. Like a lot of firms with lobbying arms, it’s playing the field to stay in the good graces of a lot of politicians. Though that’s probably a reason why a reproductive rights group should steer clear of lobbying firms.

A statement reveals that the organization is either terminally stupid or assumes you are:

Guttmacher Institute said the organization’s progressive mission is not swayed by lawyers. “Lawyers do not determine our values and positions on any issues, including unionization. Our CEO has always been very clear that Guttmacher leadership supports our staff’s desire to organize and that our management looks forward to working with the union, and this position has guided the relationship with Jackson Lewis,” a spokesperson for Guttmacher told Jezebel by email. One Friday, the union [announced a public petition](https://actionnetwork.org/letters/dfd8ec8cb8554c0a13bc152c3111cae43f0a44f5) against Jackson Lewis.

No one is saying the lawyers have determined Guttmacher’s values, they’re saying Guttmacher’s values took a back seat to securing counsel.

Again, from a legal perspective, a client can hire whoever it wants to represent it. But when entities hire attorneys who clash with the group’s mission, that’s a business problem. The bottom line is this group hired a law firm that they either knew or should have known uses firm proceeds to fund politicians seeking abortion bans. That’s just bad executive decision-making.

Because legal work is not a pocket dimension cabined off from the rest of a client’s identity. Outside counsel becomes an extension of the business and management has to consider who it chooses as its avatar. If the client has a brand identity to maintain, it’s incumbent upon leadership to make sure it’s not undermining itself.

# Biglaw Partner Dishes On the Pandemic's Impact On the Cannabis Industry, Diversity and Fulfilling Your Family's Legacy
## Choosing a practice area matters -- a lot.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 12, 2021 at 1:13 PMNovember 12, 2021 at 11:15 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-partner-dishes-on-the-pandemics-impact-on-the-cannabis-industry-diversity-and-fulfilling-your-familys-legacy/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Dishes%20On%20the%20Pandemic’s%20Impact%20On%20the%20Cannabis%20Industry,%20Diversity%20and%20Fulfilling%20Your%20Family’s%20Legacy)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-partner-dishes-on-the-pandemics-impact-on-the-cannabis-industry-diversity-and-fulfilling-your-familys-legacy/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-partner-dishes-on-the-pandemics-impact-on-the-cannabis-industry-diversity-and-fulfilling-your-familys-legacy/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In this episode, I speak with Meghana Shah, partner at Eversheds Sutherland, about why her practice area was appealing and what an average day looks like for her. We discuss how the pandemic impacted Meghana’s practice and what she thinks is on the horizon for the cannabis industry. Meghana shares her tips for others hoping to become a Biglaw partner and some of the highs and lows of her career. We also chat about why diversity has been such a challenge for the legal industry, and what Meghana thinks can be done to improve D&I efforts.

The Jabot podcast is an offshoot of the Above the Law brand focused on the challenges women, people of color, LGBTQIA, and other diverse populations face in the legal industry. Our name comes from none other than the Notorious Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the jabot (decorative collar) she wore when delivering dissents from the bench. It’s a reminder that even when we aren’t winning, we’re still a powerful force to be reckoned with.

Happy listening!


Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

####Topics

# Former Partner Sentenced To 5 Years In Prison For Scheme To Defraud Biglaw Firms
## Her future includes a minimum-security federal prison in West Virginia.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 11, 2018 at 11:18 AMMarch 14, 2019 at 2:43 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/former-partner-sentenced-to-5-years-in-prison-for-scheme-to-defraud-biglaw-firms/&text=Former%20Partner%20Sentenced%20To%205%20Years%20In%20Prison%20For%20Scheme%20To%20Defraud%20Biglaw%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/former-partner-sentenced-to-5-years-in-prison-for-scheme-to-defraud-biglaw-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/former-partner-sentenced-to-5-years-in-prison-for-scheme-to-defraud-biglaw-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The long, sordid legal drama of former Biglaw partner Keila Ravelo has finally entered the sentencing phase. Ravelo, formerly a partner at both Hunton & Williams and Willkie Farr & Gallagher, [pleaded guilty last year](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/former-willkie-partner-pleads-guilty-to-role-in-fraud-scheme/) to tax evasion and conspiracy to commit wire fraud in connection with a $7.8 million litigation vendor scheme to defraud her former firms. Yesterday, Judge Kevin McNulty of the District of New Jersey sentenced Ravelo to five years in prison with three years of supervised release.

For those who don’t remember the details of [Ravelo’s misdeeds](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/who-is-the-worst-behaved-former-biglaw-attorney/), let’s give y’all a brief primer. Ravelo, along with her now-estranged husband, Melvin Feliz, were arrested back in 2014 and indicted on charges of wire fraud and embezzlement for allegedly creating dummy corporations to funnel “legal consulting fees” — for work that was never actually done — from both of her former firms. The indictment was amended to include charges of tax evasion and using fake billings to funnel the $7.8 million they obtained in litigation support fees back to themselves for personal use, which included financing a “lifestyle of the rich and famous” — at least that’s how prosecutors describe it. The couple bought multiple properties, expensive artwork, jewelry, and private jet rides.

Feliz pleaded guilty to his role in the scheme in August 2015, and was sentenced to four years in prison. Ravelo’s sentence added an extra year on, as Law.com [reports](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/10/10/ex-big-law-partner-ravelo-sentenced-to-5-years-for-vendor-fraud-scheme/), because Judge McNulty seemed to be compelled by the prosecution’s argument that Ravelo’s breach of trust of her former firms warranted additional jail time:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It was Ravelo, not Feliz, who was a partner at Hunton and then Willkie and who had built relationships with the firms and the client, prosecutors said, and it was Ravelo who manipulated the payment mechanisms to keep the conspiracy going.

Prosecutors said Ravelo went to great lengths to keep the conspiracy going. For instance, they said, Ravelo posed as the head of one of the bogus vendors and lied to her law firm and each of her partners in order to cover up and extend the conspiracy. They also said Ravelo used people over whom she had influence to help hide her illegal activity, including at one point causing an associate she led to submit a summary chart detailing alleged vendor work product to Willkie.

The government said in 2012, after Willkie almost detected the activity, she orchestrated the payment of the bills through an accounting firm that would be reimbursed by the law firm.

Ravelo is expected to surrender by January, and was recommended to a women’s minimum-security federal prison in West Virginia.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter (@Kathryn1).

# Thanks To Omicron Variant, Elite Biglaw Firm Makes Office Work 'Voluntary' For Lawyers Through March 2022
## Things continue to change for the future of law firm office work due to COVID variants.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 15, 2021 at 1:00 PMDecember 15, 2021 at 11:31 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/goodwin-rto-march-2022/&text=Thanks%20To%20Omicron%20Variant,%20Elite%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Makes%20Office%20Work%20‘Voluntary’%20For%20Lawyers%20Through%20March%202022)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/goodwin-rto-march-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/goodwin-rto-march-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As we get closer and closer to the new year, more and more Biglaw and boutique firms seem to be getting antsy about the latest coronavirus variant. Omicron is here, and it’s even more transmissible than the delta variant. Magic Circle firms in the UK have already told their personnel to [start working from home](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/uk-magic-circle-firms-bring-back-covid-19-remote-work-requirements-thanks-to-omicron-variant/), and certain firms in the US have already [revised their return-to-office plans](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/litigation-boutique-revises-its-hybrid-return-to-office-plan-due-to-omicron-variant/) for 2022. In fact, the latest one to announce a change of plans due to omicron is one of the top firms in the country.

Goodwin Procter — a firm that brought in $1,486,263,000 gross revenue in 2020, putting it at No. 23 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking — notified employees that it would be pushing back its official reopening date to March 14, 2022.

Since November, the firm had been encouraging lawyers to work from the office at least two-to-three days each week, with plans for a fuller return in January 2022. According to a memo sent by managing partner Mark Bettencourt, the firm is making a slight change to its plans “[o]ut of an abundance of caution.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
As first reported by the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/12/14/goodwin-pushes-return-date-to-mid-march-amid-uncertainty-over-omicron-variant/), Bettencourt announced that until mid-March, “working from our U.S. offices will be entirely voluntary for our lawyers and GO! Team members.” Will other firms follow Goodwin’s lead?

What has your firm announced as far as a revised reopening plan is concerned now that the omicron variant has arrived? The more information is out there, the more likely it is that firms will be able to establish a new market standard for a return.

As soon as you find out about reopening plans at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.

[Law firms torn on office returns as COVID-19 questions swirl](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/law-firms-torn-office-returns-covid-19-questions-swirl-2021-12-14/) [Reuters]

# EVERYONE Is Getting An Above Market Bonus This Year At Irell & Manella

By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 18, 2020 at 3:56 PMDecember 18, 2020 at 3:59 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/irell-2020-bonuses/&text=EVERYONE%20Is%20Getting%20An%20Above%20Market%20Bonus%20This%20Year%20At%20Irell%20&%20Manella)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/irell-2020-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/irell-2020-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Irell & Manella is blowing the door off the Biglaw market bonus scale. And all associates are sharing in the firm’s good fortunes!

The firm[ already gave out fall bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/irell-bonuses/) (ranging between $7,500 and $40,000, depending on class year). But that’s a move [that a lot of other Biglaw firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/biglaw-fall-special-bonus-tracker-which-biglaw-firms-are-handing-out-cash-for-associates-hard-work-during-the-pandemic/) have pulled this year. But in May they also gave out supplemental bonuses, those are part of a new bonus structure that the firm says in based, in part, on profit sharing and were made after the firm’s 2019 financials closed. Now they’ve announced their year end bonuses, and for every class year, they beat the market.

Seriously, year-end market bonuses range from $15,000 to $100,000 depending on class year. At Irell they’re $25,000 to $120,000.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
So, um, Cravath who?

The firm’s bonus chart shows the jaw dropping bonuses associates can earn at the firm over the course of the year (you can read t[he full announcement on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/irell-2020-bonuses/2/)):



Earlier this year, Irell [found itself at a sort of crossroads](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/struggling-biglaw-firm-at-crossroads-again/) as the Biglaw firm announced its intention to eschew transactional work. But, if the size of these bonuses are any indication, the concerns about the new direction were overblown. And yes, the firm again intends to disburse supplemental spring bonuses after fiscal year 2020 has closed.

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Offers Major Bonuses In Major Market Offices
## Associates seem happy with their bonus haul this year.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 21, 2022 at 12:43 PMDecember 21, 2022 at 12:35 PM
24
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/perkins-coie-bonus-2022/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Offers%20Major%20Bonuses%20In%20Major%20Market%20Offices)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/perkins-coie-bonus-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/perkins-coie-bonus-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With Hannukah nearly midway through and Christmas just around the corner, Biglaw bonus season is still going strong. The largest of law firms continue to announce matches of the prevailing market rates, and this top 50 firm is no different. Bonuses at Perkins Coie are majority lockstep, and for most associates, it seems as if the firm is following where the market leads (depending on office).

The Seattle-based firm brought in $1,155,565,000 gross revenue in 2021, putting it in 42nd place on the most recent Am Law 100 ranking. Here’s what the bonus scale looks like at the firm’s major market offices:

- Class of 2021: $20,000
- Class of 2020: $30,000
- Class of 2019: $57,500
- Class of 2018: $75,000
- Class of 2017: $90,000
- Class of 2016: $105,000
- Class of 2015: $115,000
- Class of 2014+: $115,000
According to the firm’s internal announcement, some major market offices will have a bonus range for sixth-year associates and beyond, while offices located outside of major markets will have their own bonus schedules.

Congratulations on the extra bonus cash, everyone!

(Flip to the next page to see the memo from Perkins Coie.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Marc Kasowitz... Will You Accept This Rose?
## Trump choses Marc Kasowitz to defend him in the ongoing probe.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 24, 2017 at 10:44 AMJuly 12, 2017 at 10:28 AM
11
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/marc-kasowitz-will-you-accept-this-rose/&text=Marc%20Kasowitz…%20Will%20You%20Accept%20This%20Rose?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/marc-kasowitz-will-you-accept-this-rose/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/marc-kasowitz-will-you-accept-this-rose/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Yesterday Trump had narrowed down his pick for outside counsel to four. Then he decided to give the rose to… or fire the rest of… or whatever television catchphrase amounts to Kafkaesque presidential leadership these days, anyway he selected Marc Kasowitz to take the blame for upcoming revelations in the Russian collusion investigation represent him.

Meanwhile Guiffra, Olson, and Weingarten must be as relieved as group of Miss USA contestants told they can just go home — run while you can.

Kasowitz is also, of course, Joe Lieberman’s boss, a conflict of interest which would terrify the average observer aware that the firm lacks the size required to keep proper ethical walls around a conflict like this. But alas cooler heads have prevailed with reports that Lieberman will no longer pursue the FBI position, saving Orville Redenbacher from having to conjure up enough popcorn to prepare audiences for the acrobatics some senators would have come up with to justify that. Apparently having NY commercial litigator Kasowitz defend the President in a high stakes D.C. quasi-criminal investigation was more important than installing an unqualified political lackey in the FBI job. Mull on that.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
At least KBTF partner David Friedman gets to miss out on the potential ethical firestorm that could result from Trump’s latest move. Because he’s already taken on the job of [ambassador to Israel](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/kasowitz-benson-loses-name-partner-lots-of-money/).

Is it possible that Trump just forgot other firms exist?

Just asking on behalf of Jones Day.

# Don’t Waste Your Time Collecting Golden Tickets
## The downside to spending your life chasing credentials.
By [Alex Su](https://abovethelaw.com/author/alexsu/)  
onJuly 11, 2022 at 1:16 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/dont-waste-your-time-collecting-golden-tickets/&text=Don’t%20Waste%20Your%20Time%20Collecting%20Golden%20Tickets)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/dont-waste-your-time-collecting-golden-tickets/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/dont-waste-your-time-collecting-golden-tickets/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

This is just the beginning, he captioned ironically …

I went to law school because I wanted to have a big impact on the world. For some reason I told myself that could only happen if I had the right credentials. Like working at a prestigious firm and doing a fancy clerkship. That’s why I set my sights on getting admitted to a top 10 school. Which oddly enough, [includes 14 of them](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/is-t14-dead-is-it-t15-t13-was-t14-an-arbitrary-ranking-all-along/).

Something strange happened along the way, though. I found myself trying to get credentials for their own sake. I guess you kind of have to, because everything’s so competitive. It’s like I had to put on these blinders so I could properly focus on collecting as many of these [Golden Tickets](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/golden%20ticket) as I could.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“If I can just focus on this for a little while and beat everyone else,” I told myself, “I’ll be all set.”

My laser-like focus helped me win a few Golden Tickets early on. I got into a good school and ended up with decent grades after 1L year. I also somehow ended up making law review, which was unexpected. I had originally wanted to spend my time doing mock trial, which sounded a lot more fun. But everyone in my class seemed to want to be on law review, so how could I turn that down?

And, I mean, it all worked as planned. My Golden Tickets made me a highly sought-after recruit. Firms fell all over themselves trying to hire me during on-campus interviews.

Honestly, it felt good. Really good.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
It came at a price, though. Because when you spend all your time collecting Golden Tickets, you’ll find yourself doing a lot of things that aren’t aligned with your original goals. I knew that for all my “success” I didn’t actually *accomplish* anything. I didn’t help any clients. I didn’t win any cases.

I wasn’t having the impact I had always wanted.

The other thing they never tell you about these Golden Tickets, is that even after you feel like you’ve “made it,” the game doesn’t end. When I started my first week as a summer associate at my fancy Biglaw firm, I realized it was the beginning of yet another competition involving over a hundred other law students, who like me, were all from top schools. We knew this “game” would end with only one or two of us making partner.

I made myself feel better by telling myself that I had earned my place in this exclusive group of well-credentialed lawyers and law students. Wasn’t that an accomplishment in and of itself? I was a child of immigrants who never expected to be a fancy-pants corporate lawyer. This was a win, right?

That’s when I realized that I started to value the game itself. I didn’t want the ambiguity of the real world where I might not be certain about whether I was actually having an impact. My Golden Tickets gave me all the reassurance I needed.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
This delusion lasted for a while. Eventually, I came to my senses and realized that this kind of job wasn’t right for me. At the end of the day, competing for all these stupid Golden Tickets was making me unhappy. It wasn’t at all what I wanted out of my career or my life. And it was starting to impact my health and well being.

That’s when I decided to leave. In 2014, I quit Biglaw for good.

A lot has happened since then. I ended up spending a couple years doing a few things that didn’t work out, but they played a role in helping me find my place in the legal technology space. Which is where I ended up having the impact I was looking for.

If I could talk to my 20-year-old self, I’m not sure what I’d say. How would I explain my current job? What would I say that I do? “Look, you’ll end up becoming a rainmaker in the legal industry. But not as a law firm partner. They’ll call you an ‘influencer’ and [you’ll be best known for posting Tik Toks](https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2022/05/12/brand-building-101-how-in-house-counsel-can-authentically-be-seen/) and [dumb memes on social media](https://www.legalops.fm/home/the-pulse-alex-su-the-man-behind-the-meme).”

I truly believe I’ve found my place, though. Because even though I’m almost 40 and have an uncertain path ahead of me, I can see the impact I have on a day-to-day basis. Whether it’s [evangelizing technology](https://www.legaldive.com/news/avoiding-the-legal-tech-quagmire/623918/) to legal departments or highlighting all of the hard-working associates and legal professionals out there — I’m doing the kind of meaningful work I had been looking for all along.

So to those of you who are exhausted from running around collecting Golden Tickets that lead nowhere, I say, go ahead and be a little bit reckless. [Go off the beaten path](https://itsofftherecord.substack.com/p/how-to-go-off-the-beaten-path-a-summary). You don’t have to mimic [my unusual career path](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/a-funny-thing-happened-on-my-way-to-a-law-career/), but you should feel empowered to pursue something different. Don’t try to achieve conventional success by collecting all these credentials.

Because what they never tell you — especially in law school — is that “conventional success” is often anything but. They’re just proxies for success.

And they’ll never be a substitute for the real thing.

Alex Su is currently the Head of Community Development at [Ironclad](https://ironcladapp.com/), a leading legal technology company that helps accelerate the contracting process. Earlier in his career, he was an associate at Sullivan & Cromwell and clerked for a federal district judge. Alex graduated from Northwestern Pritzker School of Law, where he was an editor of the law review and the student commencement speaker. In his free time, he writes about his career journey and legal tech in his newsletter [Off The Record](http://itsofftherecord.substack.com/). You can find Alex on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/heyitsalexsu), [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/heyitsalexsu/), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/alexander-su/), and yes, even [Tik Tok](https://www.tiktok.com/@legaltechbro).

# Two Elite Firms Make It Rain Bonus Money For Their Hardest Workers
## This is what we love to see. Well done!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 16, 2021 at 12:12 PMApril 16, 2021 at 12:06 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/shep-mullin-ph-staff-bonus-2021/&text=Two%20Elite%20Firms%20Make%20It%20Rain%20Bonus%20Money%20For%20Their%20Hardest%20Workers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/shep-mullin-ph-staff-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/shep-mullin-ph-staff-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Ever since Biglaw special bonus season started, we’ve received a slew of emails from law firm support staff wondering what their fate may be as money continues to rain down upon associates. 2020 was an incredibly difficult year for everyone, and while 2021 may be a little easier, we’re still living in unprecedented times. It remains important to remember that Biglaw is not made of attorneys alone. After all, it takes an army for law firms this large to run, and the behind-the-scenes battalions of staff members deserve their due, too. That said, many firms have gone out of their way to show their support staff that they truly matter.

The latest firms to dip into their pockets to say thank you to staff are Sheppard Mullin and Paul Hastings. Exciting news for everyone!

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Last week, Sheppard Mullin offered [special bonuses to associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/am-law-100-firm-latest-to-join-bonus-parade/), and earlier this week, staff members were notified that they, too, would be receiving bonuses. Here’s an excerpt from a memo sent by chief operating officer Ted Tinson:

As the Firm has been busy, indeed, you all have been working hard. Whether you are working from home, or are part of the crew that keeps our offices running smoothly, there has been much to do. To recognize the contributions our staff has been making, the Executive Committee has approved a Staff Special Bonus of one week’s salary, payable in June. This bonus will be paid to all salaried staff and paralegals. Recipients must be active and in good standing on June 24th and payday for the bonus will be June 25th.

Thanks for all you do, folks. Stay safe, get yourselves and family members vaccinated when you are able. Step by step, a new workplace experience will come (back) to our life patterns!

Back in March, Paul Hastings offered [special bonuses to associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/paul-hastings-special-bonus-2021/), and just yesterday, staff members found out that they would also be receiving bonuses. Here’s an excerpt from a memo sent by chairman Seth Zachary and managing partners Greg Nitzkowski and Ronan O’Sullivan:

As an expression of our gratitude, we are pleased to announce that a $1,500 (or equivalent in local currency) Appreciation Bonus will be paid later this month to eligible business professionals, including regular full and part-time support staff, paralegals, other timekeepers, London and Hong Kong trainee solicitors and China Advisors. This is in recognition of the work that is being done each and every day to make our Firm great and an acknowledgement of the hard work and dedication that is being asked of team members to build on and strengthen our position in the market. …

We thank you for your commitment to excellence and greatly appreciate your contributions to the success of the Firm.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

###Above The Law In your inbox
Subscribe and get breaking news, commentary, and opinions on law firms, lawyers, law schools, lawsuits, judges, and more.

We will never sell or share your information without your consent. See our [privacy policy](/privacy-policy/).
[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 04.14.16
## * "You're not getting out of jail today." Affluenza teen Ethan Couch has been sentenced as an affluenza adult to serve four consecutive 180-day terms for each person who was killed in a fatal drunken-driving car crash he caused in 2013. The judge may reconsider Couch's sentence in two weeks. [[NBC News](http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/judge-affluenza-teen-ethan-couch-you-re-not-getting-out-n555366)] * Who will be the next chair of Baker & McKenzie? Four prominent partners have put their names forward to compete for the title. This would be much more entertaining if it were a Biglaw ladder match where we could watch Paul Rawlinson, Gary Senior, Claudia Prado, and Eric Lasry fight for the shiniest brass ring of them all. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/the-game-of-thrones-begins-at-baker-mckenzie/)] * If only law schools had more clinical opportunities for future corporate drones: Law schools have offered students more chances to perform public interest work, but this law professor worries schools are "inculcat[ing] law students with a responsibility of social justice that reflects the morality of the faculty and administration." [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/04/13/law-schools-are-indoctrinating-students-with-a-social-justice-morality-says-professor/)] * "It doesn't cry out as a triable case." Andrew Caspersen, the high-flying Harvard Law grad charged with a [$95 million fraud scheme](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/high-flying-harvard-law-grad-charged-with-95-million-fraud-scheme/), likely won't face trial. His lawyer says that he thinks his client's criminal case will be resolved within the next 60 days. He thinks the case will end in a settlement with the SEC. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/14/business/dealbook/caspersen-fraud-case-could-be-settled-lawyer-says.html)] * Sources say that Donald Trump's campaign manager Corey Lewandowski will not be [prosecuted for battery](http://www.atlredline.com/simple-battery-is-not-as-vile-as-donald-trump-1767986092) after an incident with former Breitbart reporter Michelle Fields following a press conference in March. Apparently the Palm Beach County State Attorney's Office has a "higher standard to go forward with a prosecution." [[POLITICO](http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/trump-campaign-manager-lewandowski-221921)]
[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is an editor at Above the Law. Feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, or comments. Follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 14, 2016 at 8:59 AMJuly 11, 2016 at 12:11 PM

# Morning Docket: 06.09.16
## * Let's just cut to the chase. You want to know what salary news you may have missed since you last checked in with us. Here's the roster of movement news -- good, bad, and indifferent -- from yesterday: [Cleary](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/cleary-gottlieb-matches-cravath-scale-or-maybe-beats-it/), [Simpson](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/simpson-thacher-finally-announces-its-new-salary-scale/), [Holwell](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/hot-litigation-firm-matches-cravath-salary-scale-are-boutiques-the-big-salary-bump-winners/), [Covington](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-salary-hike-not-all-offices-are-created-equal/), [Debevoise](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/debevoise-makes-its-salary-announcement-with-a-twist/), [Quinn Emanuel](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/quinn-emanuel-announces-pay-raises-for-associates/), [Winston](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/leading-biglaw-firm-raises-salaries-for-all-u-s-associates/), [SullCrom](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-announcement-youve-been-waiting-for-sullivan-cromwell/), [Kirkland](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/chicago-based-biglaw-giant-gives-raises-to-all-u-s-associates/), [Skadden](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/top-5-firm-smacks-its-associates-across-the-face-with-money/), [Freshfields](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/magic-circle-firm-matches-cravath-scale/), [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-firm-bumps-salary-to-attract-and-retain-the-best-and-brightest-attorneys/), [Davis Polk](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/guess-which-biglaw-leader-is-raising-salaries-now/). If you're ever worried that you've missed any of our coverage, check out our omnibus 2016 salary page where we collect all these stories. [[Above the Law / 2016 Salary Increase](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/2016-salary-increase/)] * Speaking of a firm that hasn't announced salary changes yet -- seamless transition! -- Dentons is having to field some tough offshore tax scandal questions. That said, since they employ 4 out of 5 lawyers in the world things like this were inevitable. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202759608263/Dentons-KPMG-Linked-to-Offshore-Tax-Scheme-Up-North?kw=Dentons%2C%20KPMG%20Linked%20to%20Offshore%20Tax%20Scheme%20Up%20North&cn=20160609&pt=Am%20Law%20Daily&src=EMC-Email&et=editorial&bu=The%20American%20Lawyer&slreturn=20160509080336)] * Former Patriots TE Aaron Hernandez hires Casey Anthony's lawyer, Jose Baez, and [Thabo Sefolosha's lawyer](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/a-wrongful-arrest-defense-clinic-the-thabo-sefolosha-story/), [Alex Spiro](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/alex-spiro/). No word on Hernandez and Baez's [fee arrangement](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/private-investigator-claims-lawyer-jose-baez-traded-his-legal-services-for-sex-with-casey-anthony/). [[Fox61](http://fox61.com/2016/06/08/aaron-hernandez-hires-casey-anthonys-lawyer/)] * The Justice Department offers 6 tips for presenting your client's merger to federal agencies. Being a top campaign bundler inadvertently left off the list. [[National Law Journal](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2016/06/08/six-tips-from-doj-for-presenting-mergers-to-federal-agencies/)] * "Trump's Terrifying Relationship With the Law." It's the bimbo he just can't leave. [[Rolling Stone](http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/trumps-terrifying-relationship-with-the-law-20160608)] * Dumb political reporting tries to make something out of an O'Melveny lawyer attending some Hillary events while working on the Trump University case. [[Politico](http://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/daniel-petrocelli-lawyer-trump-clinton-donation-224047)] * If you need to get your white slippers of albino African endangered rhino back home, don't book tickets on Delta. [[Courthouse News Service](http://www.courthousenews.com/2016/06/08/delta-airlines-need-not-transport-rhino-trophy.htm)] * In New York, there's new ethical guidance on advertising after changing firm names to reflect new partners. [[Law360](http://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/805187)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 9, 2016 at 8:52 AMJune 9, 2016 at 9:06 AM
0

* Speaking of a firm that hasn’t announced salary changes yet — seamless transition! — Dentons is having to field some tough offshore tax scandal questions. That said, since they employ 4 out of 5 lawyers in the world things like this were inevitable. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202759608263/Dentons-KPMG-Linked-to-Offshore-Tax-Scheme-Up-North?kw=Dentons%2C%20KPMG%20Linked%20to%20Offshore%20Tax%20Scheme%20Up%20North&cn=20160609&pt=Am%20Law%20Daily&src=EMC-Email&et=editorial&bu=The%20American%20Lawyer&slreturn=20160509080336)]

* Former Patriots TE Aaron Hernandez hires Casey Anthony’s lawyer, Jose Baez, and [Thabo Sefolosha’s lawyer](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/a-wrongful-arrest-defense-clinic-the-thabo-sefolosha-story/), [Alex Spiro](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/alex-spiro/). No word on Hernandez and Baez’s [fee arrangement](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/private-investigator-claims-lawyer-jose-baez-traded-his-legal-services-for-sex-with-casey-anthony/). # Goliath Law Firm Offers Raises To U.S. Associates... But How Much Depends On The Office (DLA Piper)
## We have the first reports of salary increases in a firm with a LOT of offices.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 14, 2016 at 6:41 PMJune 16, 2016 at 12:28 PM
8
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/goliath-law-firm-offers-raises-to-u-s-associates-but-how-much-depends-on-the-office/&text=Goliath%20Law%20Firm%20Offers%20Raises%20To%20U.S.%20Associates…%20But%20How%20Much%20Depends%20On%20The%20Office%20(DLA%20Piper))[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/goliath-law-firm-offers-raises-to-u-s-associates-but-how-much-depends-on-the-office/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/goliath-law-firm-offers-raises-to-u-s-associates-but-how-much-depends-on-the-office/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The world’s [third-largest law firm](https://bol.bna.com/the-worlds-largest-law-firm-will-have-7300-lawyers/) by headcount, DLA Piper, has finally announced raises for its U.S. associates. It’s a nice gesture from a firm that has so much money lying around they [hold their partner meetings on a cruise ship](https://abovethelaw.com/2013/05/law-firm-rents-entire-cruise-liner-for-partner-meeting-while-the-rest-of-you-look-for-work/). Actually, that makes you wonder why it took so long to open the coffers just a sliver.

But the wrinkle is that the firm is sending out memos on an office-by-office basis, so our intel is spotty at the moment. If you are a DLA associate or know any, remind them to send their memos in so we can feature them in this story.

For now, let’s check out the New York office raises:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  


Pretty standard stuff. Unfortunately, with a firm this size that leaves us a little in the dark about salaries at just a couple of the DLA Piper offices. Like, oh, for example:

Albany, Atlanta, Austin, TWO Baltimore locations, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, two Los Angeles locations, Miami, Minneapolis, New Jersey-South, New Jersey-North, Northern Virginia, Philadelphia, Phoenix, Raleigh, Sacramento, two San Diego offices, San Francisco, Seattle, Silicon Valley, Tampa, Washington D.C., and Wilmington.

UPDATE (6/14/16 6:50 p.m.): San Diego reports a full match of the Cravath scale. No memo as of yet.

UPDATE (6/14/16 6:51 p.m.): Silicon Valley reports a full match of the Cravath scale. Reporting the exact same graphic as posted above.

UPDATE (6/14/16 6:56 p.m.): Washington D.C. matches entirely.

UPDATE (6/14/16 7:15 p.m.): Chicago also matches entirely.

UPDATE (6/14/16 8:29 p.m.): Reports coming in that Northern Virginia has matched. Apparently those getting shorted are shy…

UPDATE (6/14/16 9:01 p.m.): San Francisco matches.

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
UPDATE (6/15/16 5:01 p.m.): We’ve got our first sense of what’s happening in offices that aren’t on the full Cravath scale. Some offices — unclear which — appear to be offering a match up through Class of ’14. After that the figures are 2013-$200k, 2012-$210k, 2011-$230k; 2007-$285k. Depending on what market you’re in, that’s not a terrible haul.

UPDATE (6/16/16 12:27 p.m.): Apparently I missed an earlier tip that Houston has also matched. Sorry about that.

What will they do in all these offices? We don’t have much to go on, but if I were a betting man, I’d guess we’ll see a lot of these offices move to $180K for first years and then compress the scale for senior associates. Kind of a recruiting bait-and-switch that maintains [salary sanity in non-NY markets](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/no-your-office-doesnt-deserve-the-ny-to-180-raise/).

So as you come across these memos, you know what to do. Whether you’re writing about DLA or some other firm, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

Meanwhile, the full NY memo is available on the next page…

# In-House Legal Have No More Excuses When It Comes To Connecting With The Right Outside Counsel
## With a new free trial, in-house lawyers should jump on Priori Legal's new Feature Lab.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 30, 2024 at 10:43 AMFebruary 6, 2024 at 5:29 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/in-house-counsel-outside-law-firms/&text=In-House%20Legal%20Have%20No%20More%20Excuses%20When%20It%20Comes%20To%20Connecting%20With%20The%20Right%20Outside%20Counsel)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/in-house-counsel-outside-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/in-house-counsel-outside-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It used to be so simple for in-house lawyers. If anything came up, just call whichever Biglaw firm spawned your GC boss and no one would ever be mad. Unfortunately, that approach might cost the firm a lot more money than necessary for the task at hand and there was no objective way to know whether the firm could actually do the job right… but it was easy.

Companies no longer enjoy that luxury. The higher-ups keep squeezing the budget and the firms keep raising the rates. But how do in-house lawyers balance finding the right-sized (read: cost) firm for the job without jeopardizing the company’s position? They used to say, “No one gets fired for hiring Cravath.” In 2024, legal departments exist like Schrödinger’s Cat trapped in limbo between being fired for spending too much and fired for spending too little.

It’s Legalweek here in New York, and that means product launches. And one of the first announcements out of the gate seeks to assist in-house counsel navigate these troubled waters.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[Priori Legal](https://www.priorilegal.com/) isn’t new to the space. Priori’s marketplace of outside counsel has helped in-house teams match the right firms with the right work for a while now, having built up a client base including Fortune 50 companies and hosting thousands of outside counsel from firms large and small and across tons of practice areas. But Priori is now offering a, for lack of a better term, “Lite” version to in-house legal teams to get a taste of what they’re missing.

Beginning on February 15, users [can get six months of free access to Priori’s newest features](https://resources.priorilegal.com/early-access-priori-feature-lab). The new “Feature Lab” includes:

The newly launched features will empower legal teams to send requests for proposals (RFPs) to their own trusted law firm networks directly through the Priori platform and leverage structured reviews and scorecards to better track and maintain knowledge about their preferred firms’ performance over time.

Importantly, legal teams will also have the option to receive proposals from Priori’s global legal marketplace of vetted law firms, lawyers, legal operations professionals and ALSPs to compare side-by-side with quotes from their own trusted law firm network, helping them select the right talent and drive cost savings when hiring for new matters.

What this sounds like to me is a clean, streamlined package that should get law departments hooked. For any in-house team still clinging to the old ways and grabbing representation from the same handful of lawyers that have served the company for decades, the Feature Lab lets them use Priori’s tool to hire their old lawyers and, oh by the way, you can benchmark that against what the marketplace offers. There doesn’t seem to be a good argument against taking Priori up on this offer.
